title: Why did hospitals have these frogs in their supply rooms? - Carly Anne York

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary use of African clawed frogs in scientific research from the 1930s to the 1960s?

options.label: A
options.text: To study the pituitary gland and its role in color changing mechanisms.

options.label: B
options.text: To test for the presence of the chorionic gonadotropin hormone (hCG) in pregnancy.

options.label: C
options.text: To study the development and behavior of amphibians.

options.label: D
options.text: To test the effectiveness of new medications.

multiple-choice.question: What was the surprising result when Lancelot Hogben injected African clawed frogs with a pituitary extract derived from an ox?

options.label: A
options.text: The frogs began to change color more rapidly.

options.label: B
options.text: The frogs began laying eggs, even without the presence of a male.

options.label: C
options.text: The frogs began to swim faster.

options.label: D
options.text: The frogs began to eat more food.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the hormone that is similar to the ox hormone and is found in the urine of pregnant people?

options.label: A
options.text: Chorionic gonadotropin hormone (hCG)

options.label: B
options.text: Pituitary hormone

options.label: C
options.text: Ovarian hormone

options.label: D
options.text: Thyroid hormone

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why African clawed frogs are now classified as an invasive species?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a high reproductive rate and can outcompete native amphibians.

options.label: B
options.text: They carry a deadly fungus called chytrid that can cause an infection in native amphibians.

options.label: C
options.text: They are difficult to care for and require specialized housing.

options.label: D
options.text: They are prone to disease and have a short lifespan.

title: Why is this black square famous? - Allison Leigh

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the painting that opened an exhibition of radical artworks in St. Petersburg, Russia in 1915?

options.label: A
options.text: "Black Square"

options.label: B
options.text: "The Suprematist Composition"

options.label: C
options.text: "The Non-Objectivity"

options.label: D
options.text: "The Feeling"

multiple-choice.question: Who is the artist behind the painting "Black Square"?

options.label: A
options.text: Kazimir Malevich

options.label: B
options.text: Vladimir Lenin

options.label: C
options.text: Leon Trotsky

options.label: D
options.text: Ivan Kramskoy

options.label: A
options.text: Suprematism

options.label: B
options.text: Futurism

options.label: C
options.text: Cubism

options.label: D
options.text: Impressionism

options.label: A
options.text: To depict real world objects in a new way

options.label: B
options.text: To create a new art that is non-representational and focuses on feeling

options.label: C
options.text: To paint everyday life scenes

options.label: D
options.text: To create a new style of abstract art

options.label: A
options.text: He was able to continue creating his Suprematist works without any restrictions

options.label: B
options.text: He was forced to abandon his Suprematist style and focus on Socialist Realism

options.label: C
options.text: He was able to teach his ideas to a new generation of artists

options.label: D
options.text: He was able to create a new style of art that was a combination of Suprematism and Socialist Realism

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Kazimir Malevich's later paintings, which were created under pressure from the Soviet authorities?

options.label: A
options.text: They were a return to his earlier Suprematist style

options.label: B
options.text: They were a combination of his earlier and later styles

options.label: C
options.text: They were a departure from his earlier style and focused on depicting real world objects

options.label: D
options.text: They were a series of abstract paintings that focused on feeling

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the tiny black square in Kazimir Malevich's self-portrait?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a symbol of his earlier Suprematist style

options.label: B
options.text: It was a symbol of his later Socialist Realist style

options.label: C
options.text: It was a symbol of his ability to create a new art that was non-representational and focused on feeling

options.label: D
options.text: It was a symbol of his ability to adapt to the changing artistic styles of the time

multiple-choice.question: What was the overall impact of Kazimir Malevich's art on the art world?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a departure from the traditional styles of art and paved the way for new and innovative styles

options.label: B
options.text: It was a return to the traditional styles of art and was widely accepted by the art world

options.label: C
options.text: It was a combination of traditional and modern styles and was widely accepted by the art world

options.label: D

title: Can you change your sleep schedule?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between an early bird and a night owl?

options.label: A
options.text: An early bird wakes up early and goes to bed early, while a night owl wakes up late and goes to bed late.

options.label: B
options.text: An early bird is a person who prefers to sleep in and wake up late, while a night owl is a person who prefers to wake up early and go to bed early.

options.label: C
options.text: An early bird is a person who is a morning person and prefers to do physical activities in the morning, while a night owl is a person who is a night person and prefers to do physical activities at night.

options.label: D
options.text: An early bird is a person who is a night person and prefers to do physical activities at night, while a night owl is a person who is a morning person and prefers to do physical activities in the morning.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why people are either early birds or night owls?

options.label: A
options.text: It is because of their genetic makeup.

options.label: B
options.text: It is because of their lifestyle and habits.

options.label: C
options.text: It is because of their circadian system.

options.label: D
options.text: It is because of their age.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the anterior hypothalamus in regulating the body's internal clock?

options.label: A
options.text: It produces hormones that regulate the body's internal clock.

options.label: B
options.text: It responds to light exposure to track the day-night cycle.

options.label: C
options.text: It regulates the body's temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: It regulates the body's blood pressure.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the body's circadian rhythm when it is exposed to consistent light and dark cycles?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes disrupted and irregular.

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes stronger and more consistent.

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same.

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes weaker and less consistent.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main benefit of maintaining a consistent sleep schedule?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps to improve cognitive function.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to improve physical health.

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to regulate the body's internal clock.

options.label: D
options.text: It helps to improve mental health.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main risk of having a disrupted circadian rhythm?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to metabolic disorders.

options.label: B
options.text: It can lead to cardiovascular disease.

options.label: C
options.text: It can lead to cancer.

options.label: D
options.text: It can lead to all of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main way to establish a contrast between bright daylight and dimmer nighttime light?

options.label: A
options.text: By using artificial lighting.

options.label: B
options.text: By getting outside in natural sunlight.

options.label: C
options.text: By using blackout curtains.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a sleep mask.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge of maintaining a sleep schedule that pushes against the body's preferences?

options.label: A
options.text: It can be difficult to establish a consistent sleep schedule.

options.label: B
options.text: It can be difficult to maintain a consistent sleep schedule.

options.label: C
options.text: It can be difficult to adjust to a new sleep schedule.

options.label: D
options.text: It can be difficult to stick to a sleep schedule.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main importance of getting enough rest for the day ahead?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps to improve cognitive function.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to improve physical health.

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to regulate the body's internal clock.

options.label: D
options.text: It helps to improve mental health.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main takeaway from the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: That everyone is a night owl.

options.label: B
options.text: That everyone is an early bird.

options.label: C
options.text: That everyone's body has a unique circadian rhythm.

options.label: D
options.text: That everyone should stick to a consistent sleep schedule.

title: Does COVID mess with your DNA?

multiple-choice.question: What is long COVID?

options.label: A
options.text: A condition that occurs immediately after COVID-19 infection.

options.label: B
options.text: A condition that occurs when the body's immune system overreacts to the virus.

options.label: C
options.text: A condition that occurs when the body experiences symptoms of illness for more than 4 weeks following infection with the SARS-CoV-2 virus.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition that occurs when the body is unable to produce antibodies to fight the virus.

multiple-choice.question: What is epigenetics?

options.label: A
options.text: The study of genetic changes that occur over time.

options.label: B
options.text: The study of the effects of environmental factors on gene expression.

options.label: C
options.text: The study of how cells decide which genes to use when.

options.label: D
options.text: The study of how genes are passed down from one generation to the next.

multiple-choice.question: What is DNA methylation?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of genetic mutation that occurs when a gene is copied incorrectly.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of epigenetic change that can affect gene expression.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of genetic change that can be inherited.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of environmental factor that can affect gene expression.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of epigenetic sticky notes in cells?

options.label: A
options.text: To mark genes for deletion.

options.label: B
options.text: To mark genes for use.

options.label: C
options.text: To mark genes for quieting down.

options.label: D
options.text: To mark genes for activation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Swedish study on DNA methylation in long COVID patients?

options.label: A
options.text: It found no difference in methylation between people with long COVID and people in remission.

options.label: B
options.text: It found that DNA methylation changes persisted after infection and were related to genes involved in regulating ACE2 and histamine signaling.

options.label: C
options.text: It found that DNA methylation changes were not related to genes involved in regulating ACE2 and histamine signaling.

options.label: D
options.text: It found that DNA methylation changes were only related to genes involved in regulating ACE2.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the US-based study on DNA methylation in long COVID patients?

options.label: A
options.text: It found that DNA methylation changes were only related to genes involved in regulating ACE2.

options.label: B
options.text: It found that DNA methylation changes persisted after infection and were related to genes involved in inflammation and response to infection.

options.label: C
options.text: It found that DNA methylation changes were not related to genes involved in inflammation and response to infection.

options.label: D
options.text: It found no difference in methylation between people with long COVID and people in remission.

multiple-choice.question: What is the connection between long COVID and chronic fatigue syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no connection between the two conditions.

options.label: B
options.text: The two conditions are caused by different viruses.

options.label: C
options.text: The two conditions share similar epigenetic changes.

options.label: D
options.text: The two conditions have different underlying mechanisms.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the finding that patients with long COVID have similar self-antibodies to patients with chronic fatigue syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: It suggests that the two conditions are caused by different viruses.

options.label: B
options.text: It suggests that the two conditions share similar underlying mechanisms.

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that the two conditions are caused by the same virus.

options.label: D
options.text: It suggests that the two conditions have different underlying mechanisms.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of epigenetic changes in understanding the connection between long COVID and chronic fatigue syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Epigenetic changes are not relevant to understanding the connection between the two conditions.

options.label: B
options.text: Epigenetic changes are relevant to understanding the connection between the two conditions, but more research is needed.

options.label: C
options.text: Epigenetic changes are a key factor in understanding the connection between the two conditions.

options.label: D
options.text: Epigenetic changes are not a key factor in understanding the connection between the two conditions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the research on epigenetic changes in long COVID patients?

options.label: A
options.text: It found that epigenetic changes are not related to the development of long COVID.

options.label: B
options.text: It found that epigenetic changes are a key factor in understanding the connection between long COVID and chronic fatigue syndrome.

options.label: C
options.text: It found that epigenetic changes are relevant to understanding the connection between long COVID and chronic fatigue syndrome, but more research is needed.

options.label: D
options.text: It found no difference in epigenetic changes between people with long COVID and people in remission.

title: The one thing stopping jellyfish from taking over - Mariela Pajuelo & Javier Antonio Quinones

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: Which is better for you: "Real" meat or "fake" meat? - Carolyn Beans

multiple-choice.question: What is flow, according to psychologists?

options.label: A
options.text: A state of deep relaxation

options.label: B
options.text: An altered state of consciousness with several defining features

options.label: C
options.text: A type of meditation

options.label: D
options.text: A form of physical exercise

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the defining features of flow?

options.label: A
options.text: Feeling easily distracted

options.label: B
options.text: Feeling effortlessly engaged in a task

options.label: C
options.text: Feeling worried or self-judgmental

options.label: D
options.text: Feeling unable to start an activity

options.label: A
options.text: It seems to stand still

options.label: B
options.text: It seems to fly by

options.label: C
options.text: It seems to be unimportant

options.label: D
options.text: It seems to be irrelevant

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They decrease

options.label: C
options.text: They remain the same

options.label: D
options.text: They become more intense

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased creativity

options.label: C
options.text: Enhanced learning

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced feelings of accomplishment

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the factors that contributes to flow?

options.label: A
options.text: Doing something you don't enjoy

options.label: B
options.text: Doing something you find intrinsically motivating

options.label: C
options.text: Doing something too easy

options.label: D
options.text: Doing something too difficult

options.label: A
options.text: Balancing personal skill level with the activity's challenge

options.label: B
options.text: Doing something you don't enjoy

options.label: C
options.text: Doing something too easy

options.label: D
options.text: Doing something too difficult

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the characteristics of flow?

options.label: A
options.text: Feeling a sense of oneness with what you're doing

options.label: B
options.text: Feeling a sense of separation from what you're doing

options.label: C
options.text: Feeling a sense of distraction from what you're doing

options.label: D
options.text: Feeling a sense of boredom from what you're doing

multiple-choice.question: What can help increase the chances of finding flow?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Setting clear end goals

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Why did Megalodon go extinct? - Jack Cooper and Catalina Pimiento

multiple-choice.question: What did Danish scientists finally conclude about certain mysterious stones in 1667?

options.label: A
options.text: That they were fallen from the sky during lunar eclipses.

options.label: B
options.text: That they were serpent tongues.

options.label: C
options.text: That they were fossilized teeth belonging to a prehistoric species called megalodon.

options.label: D
options.text: That they were used for medicinal purposes.

multiple-choice.question: What remains of megalodons are mostly scattered clues, like:

options.label: A
options.text: Fossilized bones.

options.label: B
options.text: Isolated vertebrae and lots of their enamel-protected teeth.

options.label: C
options.text: Footprints and tracks.

options.label: D
options.text: Burrows and nests.

options.label: B
options.text: Old fossil sites.

options.label: C
options.text: Food sources.

options.label: D
options.text: Budding megalodon nurseries.

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 15 meters.

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 20 meters.

options.label: D
options.text: Up to 25 meters.

options.label: A
options.text: Only in the ocean.

options.label: B
options.text: Only in coastal habitats.

options.label: C
options.text: Just about everywhere, with individuals also potentially undertaking transoceanic migrations.

options.label: D
options.text: Only in shallow waters.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The atmosphere.

options.label: D
options.text: The sea level.

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: That megalodons were omnivores.

options.label: D
options.text: That megalodons were scavengers.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated volume of megalodon's stomach?

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 5,000 liters.

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 10,000 liters.

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 15,000 liters.

options.label: D
options.text: Up to 20,000 liters.

options.label: B
options.text: 8 bites.

options.label: C
options.text: 4 bites.

options.label: D
options.text: 10 bites.

options.text: Climate change and the formation of glaciers.

options.label: B
options.text: The availability of prey species and the competition with other predators.

options.label: C
options.text: The loss of coastal habitats and the decrease in sea level.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

title: 1816: The year with no summer - David Biello

multiple-choice.question: What happened on April 10th, 1815?

options.label: A
options.text: A massive solar flare blocked the sun's rays.

options.label: B
options.text: The largest volcanic eruption in recorded history occurred on an island in present-day Indonesia.

options.label: C
options.text: A massive earthquake struck the island of Krakatoa.

options.label: D
options.text: A severe drought affected the Northern Hemisphere.

multiple-choice.question: What was the effect of the Mount Tambora eruption on the climate?

options.label: A
options.text: It caused a period of intense warming.

options.label: B
options.text: caused a period of intense super cooling.

options.label: C
options.text: caused a period of extreme drought.

options.label: D
options.text: caused a period of almost a year of hazy skies and cold weather.

multiple-choice.question: What is geoengineering?

options.label: A
options.text: A class of deliberate, large-scale interventions in Earth's natural systems intended to help restrain climate change.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of renewable energy source.

options.label: C
options.text: A method of reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

options.label: D
options.text: A way to increase the Earth's temperature.

multiple-choice.question: What is solar radiation management?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of geoengineering that involves reducing the amount of sunlight reaching the Earth's surface.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of geoengineering that involves increasing the amount of sunlight reaching the Earth's surface.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of geoengineering that involves reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of geoengineering that involves increasing greenhouse gas emissions.

multiple-choice.question: Why are some scientists interested in using sulfurous haze to block out the sun?

options.label: A
options.text: To cause a period of intense super cooling.

options.label: B
options.text: To slow the effects of global warming.

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the amount of sunlight reaching the Earth's surface.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why solar radiation management is risky?

options.label: A
options.text: It can cause a period of intense super cooling.

options.label: B
options.text: It can cause a period of intense super warming.

options.label: C
options.text: It can create unpredictable ripple effects in the Earth's climate system.

options.label: D
options.text: It can reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between geoengineering and reducing greenhouse gas emissions?

options.label: A
options.text: Geoengineering is a type of renewable energy source, while reducing greenhouse gas emissions is a type of fossil fuel.

options.label: B
options.text: Geoengineering is a type of geoengineering that involves reducing greenhouse gas emissions, while reducing greenhouse gas emissions is a type of geoengineering that involves increasing greenhouse gas emissions.

options.label: C
options.text: Geoengineering is a type of geoengineering that involves reducing the amount of sunlight reaching the Earth's surface, while reducing greenhouse gas emissions is a type of geoengineering that involves increasing the amount of sunlight reaching the Earth's surface.

options.label: D
options.text: Geoengineering is a type of geoengineering that involves reducing greenhouse gas emissions, while reducing greenhouse gas emissions is a type of geoengineering that involves removing CO2 from the air.

multiple-choice.question: Why are some scientists interested in studying the impacts of geoengineering?

options.label: A
options.text: To cause a period of intense super cooling.

options.label: B
options.text: To slow the effects of global warming.

options.label: C
options.text: To prepare for the possibility that someone may start geoengineering without governmental approval.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why geoengineering might be civilization's last resort?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it can cause a period of intense super cooling.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it can create unpredictable ripple effects in the Earth's climate system.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it can be a shockingly easy way to execute large-scale interventions in the Earth's climate system.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it can reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

multiple-choice.question: Why is climate change an unintended geoengineering project?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a type of geoengineering that involves reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a type of geoengineering that involves increasing greenhouse gas emissions.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a type of geoengineering that involves removing CO2 from the air.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a type of geoengineering that involves large-scale interventions in the Earth's climate system fueled by the emissions generated from centuries of burning fossil fuels.
